Package curam.util.client.domain

Domain-related processing classes for the client infrastructure, most of which can be overridden to perform custom processing.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ClientDomain Extends the basic Domain interface to provide access to client-specific plug-ins.
 

Class Summary
AbstractClientDomainPlugIn A base class for client domain plug-ins.
ClientDomainOptions Provides client-specific accessors for the options defined in the UML model.
 

Package curam.util.client.domain Description

Domain-related processing classes for the client infrastructure, most of which can be overridden to perform custom processing. More information on domain-related processing and customization can be found in the Curam Web Client Reference Manual.

The main unit of customization is the "domain plug-in". There are several types of domain plug-in, each type performs a particular kind of processing. The client infrastructure associates domain plug-ins with domain definitions (defined in the UML model) and then invokes these plug-ins at key points in the processing of the application data. These associations between domain plug-ins and domain definitions can be overridden as required and custom plug-ins can be written to effect the required custom processing.

The available plug-in types are as follows:

  • comparator - Compares values when sorting and therefore controls the sort order of the data displayed on list pages. Defined by the DomainComparator interface.
  • default - Provides default values when no other values are available. The default values can be displayed in form fields to speed the entry of data by users. Defined by the DomainDefault interface.
  • converter - Converts data from the application server into the string format displayed on the web page and parses the string format entered by the user to the type required by the application server. This interface also provides support for ad hoc validation of the parsed data. Defined by the DomainConverter interface.
  • view-renderer - Marks up the formatted data of a read-only field with HTML for display on the web page. Defined by the DomainRenderer interface.
  • edit-renderer - Marks up the formatted data of a modifiable field with HTML for display on the web page. Defined by the DomainRenderer interface.
  • select-renderer - Marks up the formatted data of a modifiable field with HTML for display on the web page where that field offers a selection from a list of available values. Defined by the DomainRenderer interface.
  • marshal - Assembles data split over several form fields by a renderer plug-in into a single value that can be submitted to the application server after parsing by the converter. Defined by the DomainMarshal interface.

The different "renderer" plug-ins all implement the same interface, but they are configured separately. The type of renderer that is invoked depends on the combination of data connections for that field. For example, if the field has no target connections, a "view-renderer" will be selected.

N.B.: The plug-in life cycle is managed by the infrastructure. Each plug-in also has access to basic context information such as the domain with which it is associated and the active user's locale and time zone. This life cycle management and context information is only available through the abstract plug-in implementation classes provided by the infrastructure. For all plug-ins, the basic interface must not be implemented directly. Rather, the appropriate abstract base class (documented in the interfaces), or an existing plug-in implementation class must be used as the base class for any custom plug-in implementation.

N.B.: Plug-in objects are instantiated when the initial associations are made with the domain definitions modeled by the client infrastructure at run-time. After this point, plug-in objects are re-used for efficiency. A single plug-in object may be re-used concurrently on multiple threads when serving the requests of multiple users. For example, several users may make simultaneous requests for pages that all require the formatting of date-time values. Plug-in methods are not synchronized, so plug-in implementations must be thread-safe, i.e., stateless and re-entrant. The only state information is the inherited plug-in context information, and this is managed by the infrastructure to ensure that it is thread-safe. The implementation classes should never define instance fields to store values, as these are highly likely to introduce concurrency problems that might not be apparent during basic testing.
